newsitem.title: USA: INSIGHT - June T-bond seen testing upside targets.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT - June T-bond seen testing upside targets.

text.p: Technicians are eyeing the upper 109-00 handle in June U.S. Treasury bond futures after a pair of bullish economic reports propelled the contract to its highest price in over a month.
June bond futures soared to a high of 108-29 early Tuesday, for a 1-1/2-point gain, on bullish surprises in U.S. data on wages and demand for big-ticket items.
The first-quarter employment cost index posted a weaker than forecast 0.6 percent rise, while orders for durable goods fell 3.0 percent in March, the biggest drop since August 1996.

On the bond floor, traders and analysts said the data, particularly the employment cost index, had forced many market participants to reconsider their positions. A lot of shorts were covered in the aftermath of the report, though a sizable portion have hung in, floor traders said.
This morning's peak in June bonds was the highest price the contract had reached since the Federal Reserve raised short-term rates by 25 basis points on March 25.
At midsession, June bond futures remained near the day's high at 108-24, up 1-11/32.
Some technicians are now looking for the contract to revisit the March 25 high of 109-25.
Nike Kalivas, senior credit market analyst for Refco Inc, sees the June bond poised to test a series of former weekly lows from 109-14 to 109-26.

"If it can close above that region on a weekly basis, bonds could be headed for a deeper rally and a possible reversal," he said. He identified 111-08, the halfway point on the climb back to the December highs from the recent low of 106-12, as a likely target if the bond rally is extended.
A technician on the bond floor said he was targeting the 50-day moving average at 109-16 to 109-17 and the 200-day moving average at 109-30 as upside goals for the June bond.
On a pullback, futures need to stay above the former resistance level of 108-06 to keep the rally alive, he added.
The market is likely to continue to probe higher in the short term as the upper limits of the turnabout are explored, several traders argued.
However, others thought bond futures could simply consolidate for the rest of the week as they head into Friday's April employment report.
"I think I want to see a couple of days of trading before I decide what to do," said a floor broker who had been bearish before this morning.
